I strongly doubt liquid nitrogen would be effective to mitigate such a 'modest catastrophy'.

Firstly, the Leidenfrost effect will prevent the liquid nitrogen from cooling the sodium at a fast rate.
Worse, the sudden conversion of liquid N2 to a large volume of gas will cause an explosion, throwing hot molten sodium around.

However, even if we ignore that: solidifying 12.5 tonnes of liquid sodium would require 3.22 tonnes of liquid N2, or about 4000 liters of it. That dewar does not even come close. The almost man-sized one dewar vessel he stands next to It may seem large, but it can contain at most 200 liters, probably much less.

And then I am ignoring the fact that the sodium needs to cool down from the high temperature to its melting point first, which will require additional nitrogen.

Nice video. There is however some missleading affirmations in it.
The dynamo effect was in fact already observed, about 10 years ago, by the french VKS experiment team (VKS stands for Von Karmann Sodium). Since they are the ones who discovered this effect, it might be interesting to contact them to get more info, but we kind of know what will be observed in this experiment, since we already did.
Of course, the geometry is slightly changed and the conditions are closer to the earth, so this experiment, will bring in interesting new information anyway.
My second point, I'm not entirely sure and you'd have to get the opinion of more experts on the topic (usually consulting only one of the opposing teams on a topic is always going to get you something biased btw). However, from what I understood, it seems that the dynamo effect is a chaotic effect. So, much like the weather even if you make a very good model of it, you actually cannot predict what will happen past a certain amount of time. It's not that your model is not good enough, it's that it is so sensitive to infinitesimal perturbations of the starting conditions that it is actually impossible to predict far in the future. So unlike what Pr Lathrop suggests, it seems to me that we do have a very good idea of whether we can predict the magnetic's field reversions or not.

???? It's a bit unrelated but I'm seem to be a tad confused here. I find the definition of action concerning the core of the earth (much less this experiment) a tad difficult to follow. From what I understand about centrifugal/centripetal motion, 'centrifugal' motion (I know, I know. it's not a 'real' force) causes heavier mass to be thrown outward away from the axis of rotation. Whereas 'centripetal' dictates 'toward the center' for lighter mass materials (which I've seen demonstrated time and again). The two must work hand in hand as 'reactive forces' to exist. Think not? Ever been on a 'rotor ride' at a carnival where you stand against the wall, the ride spins, the bottom drops away and you stick to the wall? Centrifugal force.

If this is the case, how is it that a solid iron core and molten iron (much heavier than molten and solid rock) maintain their position at the center of earth? Especially considering that the earth spins on its' axis fast enough to cause a bulge at it's equator and rotates at a velocity nearly twice the speed of sound at its' equator at a diameter of roughly 8,000 miles. This device spins at only four revolutions per second (80 mph). But then again, mechanism is encased by a solid metal shell (and still they seem worried about overcoming material stress) whereas the earth (by current definition) is essentially little more than a mushy flexible mass of molten rock covered by a thin cracked shell of solid rock that's constantly being jostled around with a solid iron core that somehow maintains itself at the center of this spinning mass and held together by nothing more than the weakest force known. Gravity.

So, what happened to centrifugal/centripetal action here? I understand from the diagram and the definition given on this video that this three meter sphere contains a one meter solid metal (I would have to assume) core that is fixed in place so it can't move. Fair enough. It also contains several tons of molten sodium confined within the outer shell which rotates. At the very least, who's to say that there aren't huge voids within or just under earths' mantle? Just curious.

Correction: We don't have a predictive model for the magnetic field that is at all accurate under evolutionary theory. The Dynamo Theory is the one being tested in the video, and it does have predictions...they just aren't accurate. It should be accurate when predicting other planets' magnetic fields, however, it has not been, hence why more answers are needed. There is another model that does accurately predict the Earth's, and most importantly, proved itself by accurately predicting other planets' magnetic fields before being measured, including predicting change over several years. It's called the Rapid Decay Theory, and you can read about it here: https://bit.ly/2mlFaww. Either way, more research is still needed to better understand the magnetic field's reversals and to be able to increase precision of predicting the Earth's magnetic field to the point where we can predict not just the average strength of the magnetic field over the years, but what it will do day to day.

Looking at the diagram at 3:57 I was wondering, what if the convective spirals were more conductive than the surrounding liquid. You would get more current flowing in those spirals and those spirals would then be like coils of wire with current flowing through them which results in a magnetic field aligned along the spirals which are aligned with the earth's axis of rotation. Those convective spirals are essentially just giant inductors. If there was some kind of capacitive element connected to these inductors then you could get the magnetic field to oscillate like it has been observed to do so. The energy storage system wouldn't necessarily have to be capacitive, if the current induced by the collapsing magnetic field was converted to mechanical force then perhaps it could be stored in something that acts like a spring or perhaps as faster flowing liquid, which then gets converted back to current when the magnetic field stops driving the current.

As far as where the current came from, random chance. Given enough time, electrons will arrange themselves in an unstable order randomly and cause current to flow to restabilize, and this triggers the chain reaction of the growing magnetic field which is maintained solely by rotational energy, as long as the core stays a fluid.

The problem is, since there is no original magnetic field to maintain polarity, the polarity is unstable, and will regularly flip. This means one day, the north pole will be the south pole and the south pole will be the north pole. This is actually less of a problem for humans than it is animals, who have adapted to the polarity of earths magnetic field. Migratory animals will have a rough time. I think the 'weakening' of the magnetic field isn't a weakening at all, but a sign of a pole reversal, which we know is due.
